title: 109_hr5612
content: The Act may be cited as the "Chattahoochee National Forest Act of 2006". It establishes the Mountaintown National Scenic Area within the Chattahoochee National Forest in Georgia. The Mountaintown National Scenic Area is established in the Chattahoochee National Forest in Georgia, encompassing 13,382 acres. The Secretary of Agriculture will provide a final map and boundary description to Congress, with the same legal effect as if included in the Act. The map and boundary description for the Mountaintown National Scenic Area in the Chattahoochee National Forest shall be on file for public inspection. Any discrepancies between the acreage and the map will be resolved by the map and boundary description required by the Secretary. Management of the scenic area will be for specific purposes determined by the Secretary. The Secretary will manage the Mountaintown National Scenic Area to protect and preserve its scenic quality, water quality, natural characteristics, and water resources. This includes managing vegetation for wildlife habitat, developing old-growth forest characteristics, and providing recreational opportunities. The Secretary will develop a management plan for the Mountaintown National Scenic Area within three years, prioritizing management purposes over general laws and regulations. After the enactment of this Act, the Secretary will develop a management plan for the scenic area as an amendment to the Chattahoochee National Forest's land and resource management plan. No new roads can be constructed within the scenic area after the enactment date. Vegetation management in the scenic area prohibits timber harvest except for fire, insects, diseases control, public safety, and trail access. The Secretary can conduct vegetation manipulation for wildlife clearings and visual quality maintenance. Personal firewood harvesting is allowed along perimeter roads under specified conditions. Motorized travel is not allowed in the scenic area, except for administrative use and wildlife management projects. Wildfires will be suppressed in a manner consistent with management purposes. The scenic area is managed to control insect and disease outbreaks, maintain water quality, and withdraw federally owned lands from mining activities. Designation of approximately 8,448 acres in Georgia as wilderness under the Wilderness Act, adding three areas to the Southern Nantahala Wilderness. Designation of new wilderness areas in Georgia: Ben Gap, Shoal Branch, Tate Branch, Cedar Mountain, Duck Branch, Wilson Cove, Ellicott Rock Addition, Foster Branch, and Ken Mountain, totaling approximately 8,448 acres. Designation of new wilderness areas in Georgia includes additions to Cohutta Wilderness (Foster Branch - 165 acres, Ken Mountain - 527 acres), Raven Cliffs Wilderness (Helton Creek - 2,451 acres), and Tray Mountain Wilderness (Tripp Branch - 638 acres). Final maps and boundary descriptions will be submitted to Congress after the enactment of this Act. Final maps and boundary descriptions of designated wilderness lands will have the same legal effect as if included in the Act, with the Secretary able to correct errors. The maps will be available for public inspection. The Secretary will administer the wilderness areas in accordance with the Wilderness Act and this section. The Secretary will administer designated wilderness lands in accordance with the Wilderness Act and this section, with the effective date of the Wilderness Act deemed to be the date of enactment of this Act. Nothing in this section will affect fish and wildlife jurisdiction. The Wilderness Act designates federal land as wilderness, withdrawing it from various forms of use, while preserving Georgia's jurisdiction over fish and wildlife in the Chattahoochee National Forest.
